byline.contributor: Michael D. Shear reported from Birmingham, Ala., and Jessica Silver-Greenberg from New York.
byline.original: By MICHAEL D. SHEAR and JESSICA SILVER-GREENBERG

abstract: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau proposes regulations to rein in what are seen as predatory payday loans that often have interest rates of 400 percent or more; rules would cover most of $46 billion market that serves working poor.
lead_paragraph: The rules proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would require lenders to assess customers’ ability to repay short-term loans.

headline.main: Payday Loan Rules Proposed by Consumer Protection Agency
headline.print_headline: Agency Aims to Rein In Loans Seen as Predatory

snippet: The rules proposed by the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau would require lenders to assess customers’ ability to repay short-term loans.
